units.cheatsheet:
## Concepts in Focus React JS Why React JS? Advantages of React JS Running JavaSript in HTML Creating Elements using React JS React CDN React.createElement() Displaying Element JSX Babel Embedding Variables and Expressions in JSX Nesting JSX elements Including External JS File in HTML
## 1. React JS React JS is an open-source JavaScript library used to build user interfaces. It was developed by Facebook. ### 1.1 Why React JS? - Performant websites - Fewer lines of code - Improves readability of code - Less time consuming - Open Source - Reusable code ### 1.2 Advantages of React JS - Easy to Learn - Large Community - Developer Toolset
## 2. Running JavaScript in HTML We can run JavaScript in HTML using the HTML `script` element. It is used to include JavaScript in HTML. ```html
``` Here the `type` attribute specifies the type of the script. To include an external JavaScript file, we can use the HTML `script` element with the attribute `src`. The `src` attribute specifies the path of an external JS file. ```html ``` When the browser comes across a `script` element while loading the HTML, it must wait for the script to download, execute it, and only then it can process the rest of the page. So, we need to put a `script` element at the bottom of the page. Then the browser can see elements above it and doesn’t block the page content from showing. If more than one `script` elements are in the HTML, the `script` elements will be executed in the order they appear.
## 3. Creating Elements using React JS ### 3.1 React CDN ```html ``` ### 3.2 React.createElement() The `React.createElement()` method is used to create an element using React JS. It is similar to the `document.createElement()` method in regular JavaScript. **Syntax**: ```terminal React.createElement(type, props); ``` **type** - Tag names like `div`, `h1` and `p`, etc. **props** - Properties like `className`, `onClick` and `id`, etc. Props are shorthand for properties. It is an optional argument. ```html ``` The `type` attribute value of the HTML `script` element should be `module` to run React JS. ### 3.3 Displaying Element The `ReactDOMClient.createRoot()` lets us to create a root element to display React Elements inside a browser DOM **Syntax**: ```terminal ReactDOMClient.createRoot(container); ``` The `root.render()` displays a React node into the React root’s browser DOM node **Syntax**: ```terminal root.render(reactElement); ``` **reactElement** - What to render **container** - Where to render ```html
```
## 4. JSX React JS introduced a new HTML like syntax named JSX to create elements. ```jsx const element =

Hello World

; ``` The above JSX element compiles to, ```js const elementProps = { className: "greeting"}; const childrenContent = "Hello World!"; const element = React.createElement(elementType, elementProps, childrenContent); ``` In JSX, HTML tags always need to be closed. For example, `
`, ``. ### 4.1 Babel JSX is not JavaScript. We have to convert it to JavaScript using a code compiler. Babel is one such tool. It is a JavaScript compiler that translates JSX into regular JavaScript. Import babel in head tag. ```html ``` ```html ``` - For JSX, the `type` attribute value of the HTML `script` element should be `text/babel`. - For providing class names in JSX, the attribute name should be `className`. **Differences between HTML and JSX**: | HTML | JSX | | ----- | --------- | | class | className | | for | htmlFor | ### 4.2 Embedding Variables and Expressions in JSX We can embed the variables and expressions using the flower brackets `{}`. **Embedding variables in JSX**: ```html
``` **Embedding Expressions in JSX**: ```html
``` ### 4.3 Nesting JSX elements The `ReactDOM.render()` method returns only one element in render. So, we need to wrap the element in parenthesis when writing the nested elements. ```html
```

## 1. Component A Component is a JS function that returns a JSX element. ```jsx const Welcome = () =>

Hello, User

Hello, User

; const root = ReactDOMClient.createRoot(document.getElementById("root")); root.render(); ``` #### 1.1.2 Accessing Props The components accept props as parameters and can be accessed directly. **Syntax**: ```js const Component = (props) => { // We can access props here }; ``` ```jsx const Welcome = (props) => { const { name, greeting } = props; return (

## 2. Real World React Apps Creating a real-world app involves lot of setup because a large number of components need to be organised. **Evan You**, the creator of **Vue.js** created a **third-party package vite** to generate a ready-made react application setup ### 2.1 NPM (Node Package Manager) [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) is a **package manager** with millions of packages, serving as a repository and tool for managing JavaScript project dependencies NPM Company provides a **Command line tool** which will allow you to **publish, discover, install, and develop** node programs #### 2.1.1 Creating a React app using Vite ```terminal npm create vite@8.0.2 ``` Then Give the app name, Select framework (as React) and variant (as JavaScript) ``` > root@123/.../.../# npm create vite@8.0.2 ✔ Project name: … myapp ✔ Select a framework: > React ✔ Select a variant: > JavaScript ✔ Use rolldown-vite(Experimental): > No ✔ Install with npm and start now: > Yes ``` #### 2.1.2 React Application Folder Structure Let’s quickly understand the core structure of the folders. We have 2 primary ones: - public/folder: Where we will keep assets like images, icons, videos etc - src/folder: Where we will do the majority of our work. All of our React components will placed here. The **main.jsx** is a starting point to the Application **package.json** JSON file containing the configuration for the project, including dependencies and other project details JavaScript files containing JSX syntax should be named with **.jsx** extension #### 2.1.3 Starting a React Application Install the dependencies and run **npm run dev** command from **myapp** directory ```terminal nxtwave@RJSIVIMLDB:~/components-and-props$ cd myapp nxtwave@RJSIVIMLDB:~/components-and-props/myapp$ npm run dev ``` You can view the application in the URL `http://localhost:3000` in your browser. ### 2.2 Pre-Configured tools The `create vite` comes pre-configured with: - **Live editing**: Allows **React components** to be live reloaded. - **Esbuild & Rollup**: These are tools used to stitch together a group of modules into a single file (or group of files) This process is called **Bundling** esbuild is also a **JavaScript Compiler**, compiles **JSX into Regular JavaScript**.

## Concepts in Focus Keys Keys as Props Users List Application
## 1. Keys `Keys` help React to identify which items have changed, added, or removed. They should be given to the elements inside the array for a stable identity. The best way to pick a `key` is to use a string that uniquely identifies a list item among its siblings. Most often, we would use IDs (`uniqueNo`) from our data as `keys`. **Example**: ```jsx const userDetails = [ { uniqueNo: 1, imageUrl: "https://assets.ccbp.in/frontend/react-js/esther-howard-img.png", name: "Esther Howard", role: "Software Developer", }, ]; ``` **File**: src/App.jsx ```jsx import UserProfile from "./components/UserProfile/index"; const userDetailsList = [ { uniqueNo: 1, imageUrl: "https://assets.ccbp.in/frontend/react-js/esther-howard-img.png", name: "Esther Howard", role: "Software Developer", }, { uniqueNo: 2, imageUrl: "https://assets.ccbp.in/frontend/react-js/floyd-miles-img.png", name: "Floyd Miles", role: "Software Developer", }, { uniqueNo: 3, imageUrl: "https://assets.ccbp.in/frontend/react-js/jacob-jones-img.png", name: "Jacob Jones", role: "Software Developer", }, { uniqueNo: 4, imageUrl: "https://assets.ccbp.in/frontend/react-js/esther-devon-lane.png", name: "Devon Lane", role: "Software Developer", }, ]; const App = () => (

Users List

{userDetailsList.map((eachItem) => ( ))}
); export default App; ``` The `index.jsx` file in the folder is considered to be the main file in it. So, a path like `./components/UserProfile` can be used instead of `./components/UserProfile/index`. Keys used within arrays should be unique among their siblings. However, they don't need to be unique in the entire application. ### 1.1 Keys as Props **Keys don't get passed as a prop to the components**. ```jsx const UserProfile = (props) => { const { userDetails, key } = props; const { imageUrl, name, role } = userDetails; console.log(key); return (

## 1. Components There are two ways to write React Components. They are: - Functional Components - Class Components ### 1.1 Functional Components These are JavaScript functions that take props as a parameter if necessary and return react element (JSX). ```jsx const Welcome = () =>

Hello, User

; export default Welcome; ``` ```jsx import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; const App = () => { return ; }; export default App; ``` The component name should always be in the pascal case.
## 2. Building a Counter App **Steps** - Build a Static Version in React - Add Event Listeners - Update Count based on User Actions ### 2.1 Build a Static Version in React To start with, we have provided components/Counter folder and corresponding files Now, lets build a static version of the application. **File**: src/components/Counter/index.jsx ```jsx import "./index.css"; const Counter = () => { return (

Counter

0

); }; export default Counter; ``` **File**: src/App.jsx ```jsx import Counter from "./components/Counter"; const App = () => ; export default App; ``` ### 2.2 Add Event Listeners Adding Inline Events using JSX is very similar to adding Events in HTML We should not call the function when we add an event in JSX **Mistake** ```jsx|UGLY onClick={onIncrement()} ``` **Solution** ```jsx|CLEAN onClick={onIncrement} ``` **File**: src/components/Counter/index.jsx ```jsx import "./index.css"; const Counter = () => { const onIncrement = () => { console.log("Increment clicked"); }; return (

Counter

0

); }; export default Counter; ```
## 3. State In React, State is a built-in mechanism where we **store** the **Component’s data that changes over the time** When the data in the **state changes, the component re-renders** Entire Component will be called
## 4. React Hooks **React Hooks** are special functions that are a new addition to React They allow us to use **State** and other **React features** in the **Function Components** | Hook | Purpose | | ------------ | ---------------------------------------- | | useState()\* | Add State to Function Components | | useEffect() | Execute Logic after the Component render | | useContext() | Access the Context value | ### 4.1 State Hook State Hook is a built-in Hook that allows us to add **state** to the **Function Components** **Syntax** ``` const [currentState, setterFun] = useState(initialValue) ``` The useState returns an **array** with two values: the **current state** and a **function** to update it The **Initial value** can be of any **data type** ### 4.2 Maintaining Count in the State Here, the count is **changing over the time**, So it should be maintained in the **State** Import the `useState` as below mentioned snippet. ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; ``` **File**: src/components/Counter/index.jsx ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import "./index.css"; const Counter = () => { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); return (

Counter

{count}

); }; export default Counter; ``` ### 4.3 Updating State - The **Setter function** is used to update the state - It accepts either a **value or a callback function** as an argument If the next state is **independent** of the **previous state**, update state with the **next state value** ```jsx setterFun(nextValue) ``` If the next state is **computed** based on the **previous state**, we can use **callback function** to update the state ```jsx setterFun(prevState => nextState) ``` Here in our scenario, the next state **can be computed** from the previous state ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import "./index.css"; const Counter = () => { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); const onIncrement = () => { setCount(prevCount => prevCount+1) } return (

Counter

{count}

); }; export default Counter; ``` ### 4.4 Decreasing Counter Value Now, Lets handle decreasing the counter value ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import "./index.css"; const Counter = () => { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); const onIncrement = () => { setCount(prevCount => prevCount+1) } const onDecrement = () => { setCount(prevCount => prevCount-1) } return (

Counter

{count}

); }; export default Counter; ```
## 5. React Developer Tools React Developer Tools is a Chrome **extension** which you can use to **debug** a **React application** **Installing React Developer Tools** - Search Chrome Extensions - Search React Developer Tools - Click Add to Chrome Button Refresh the Page, if page is already opened to enable extension On installing React Developer Tools extension you get two tabs added to your browser developer tools - Components - Profiler **Component Tree** Shows all the **components** in **tree structure** Here, We can select the **props** of the **components** and modify them

## Concepts in Focus Conditional Rendering Using an If...Else Statement Using Element Variables Using Ternary Operators Using Logical && Operator Common Mistake
## 1 . Conditional Rendering **Conditional Rendering** allows us to render different elements or components based on a condition. Different ways to implement **Conditional Rendering** are: - Using an If...Else Statement - Using Element Variables - Using Ternary Operators - Using Logical && Operator Lets take an example and understand this. Consider the below inital codes. **File**: src/App.jsx ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); return (

Hello, User

); }; export default App; ``` **File**: src/components/Welcome.jsx ```jsx import "./index.css"; const Welcome = (props) => { const { name, greeting } = props; return (

{greeting}, {name}

); }; export default Welcome; ``` ### 1.1 Using an If...Else Statement ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); const renderAuthButton = () => { if (isLoggedIn === true) { return ; } return ; }; return (
{renderAuthButton()}
); }; export default App; ``` ### 1.2 Using Element Variables ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); let authButton; if (isLoggedIn === true) { authButton = ; } else { authButton = ; } return (
{authButton}
); }; export default App; ``` ### 1.3 Using Ternary Operators ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); return (
{isLoggedIn ? : }
); }; export default App; ``` ### 1.4 Using Logical && Operator ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); return (
{isLoggedIn && } {!isLoggedIn && }
); }; export default App; ``` Conditional Rendering can be achieved using inline styles or adding classes with CSS `display` property with value `none`. However, it is not preferable.
## 2. Common Mistake Prop name not being passed accurately for any React Component **Example**: **File**: src/components/Welcome/index.jsx ```jsx import "./index.css"; const Welcome = (props) => { const { name, greetings } = props; return (

{greetings}, {name}

); }; export default Welcome; ``` **File**: src/App.jsx ```jsx import { useState } from "react"; import Welcome from "./components/Welcome"; import "./App.css"; const App = () => { const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(true); return (
{isLoggedIn && } {!isLoggedIn && }
); }; export default App; ``` As you can see in the above example, In App.jsx, while passing the prop, we are giving the prop name as `greeting` But, In the component, we are accessing the prop we are accessing it as `greetings` So, when we execute it, the `greetings` will have the value as `undefined` So, It is very important that the **props that you pass and the props that you access**, have the same name.

units.cheatsheet:
## Introduction AI is revolutionizing the way we build websites. In this unit we will build a static website using Gen AI and understand the importance of learning technologies to make the best use of Generative AI ## 1. Introduction to GenAI in Frontend Development ### 1.1. Static Website A static website is an application that contains fixed content and displays the same information to every visitor in the same way **Technologies Used** These websites involve limited user interactions, and each page is primarily developed using HTML and CSS technologies **Examples of Static Websites** - LibraryDashboard - ShoppingPortal - Modern Dashboard - CourseCatalog - RecipeBook - Sign Up Form In this unit, we will take a sample static portfolio website and build that using Generative AI ### 1.2. Developing a Web Application #### 1.2.1 Design/Mock up In real-world software development, you will be provided with a reference, commonly known as a design file or mockup, that outlines what you need to develop Mockup Design : Image ### 1.3. ## 1. Leveraging Gen AI for accelerated learning Generative AI has the potential to accelerate learning in web development, particularly when building static websites with HTML and CSS. ### 1.1. The Role of Gen AI in Learning HTML and CSS - Gen AI can act as your tutor, available 24/7. - It provides explanations, breaks down tough concepts, and even quizzes you. - This ensures that learning HTML and CSS becomes faster and more efficient.
### 1.2. How Gen AI Enhances Learning in HTML/CSS **1.2.1 Learning a Concept:** Gen AI helps by breaking down difficult topics into simple terms using analogies and examples
Prompt
Act as if you are an expert with 20 years of experience in developing static websites with HTML & CSS. Break down the core principles of `{Topic name}` in a way that a complete beginner can understand. Use simple analogies, step-by-step logic, and simplify everything as if I were 5 years old.
**1.2.2 Clarifying a Concept:** When you have doubts about a concept, Gen AI can provide immediate clarification
Prompt 1
Act as if you are an expert with 20 years of experience in developing static websites with HTML & CSS. I am learning about `{Topic name}`. I am specifically confused about `{doubt}`. Please clarify this specific point for me and break down the explanation into smaller, easier-to-understand parts. Use simple analogies, real-world examples to simplify the concept and simplify everything as if I were 5 years old.
Prompt 2
Let’s dive into learning Static Website HTML/CSS, a `{Topic name}` I am really curious about! I would like you to ask me questions to help me explore and understand this subject better. We will work together to build a solid foundation, and you will provide feedback to help me identify any misconceptions or gaps in my understanding—kind of like using the Feynman technique. Feel free to ask specific questions that challenge my understanding of HTML and CSS. It doesn’t matter if I can’t answer them right away; my goal is to learn and improve more and more.Let’s begin!
**1.2.3 Testing your Knowledge:** Gen AI can generate quizzes and gives you coding questions to test your understanding of concepts.
Prompt 1
I just finished learning about `{Topic name}`. Could you create a comprehensive quiz to test my understanding of this concept by following these guidelines: - Present each question one at a time, in sequential order. - Wait for my response after each question before moving to the next one. - Provide immediate feedback after each answer, including detailed explanations and reasoning behind the correct answer. - Track my progress throughout the quiz and let me know how I am doing at each step. - If I get an answer wrong, kindly provide hints or further resources to help me understand the concept better.
Prompt 2
You are an HTML and CSS tutor for school and first-year engineering students. Your goal is to ask one coding question on static website at a time based on the provided concepts. Concepts : `{Topic name}` Guidelines : - Ask one detailed question at a time based only on the concepts explicitly mentioned. - Do not introduce any new concepts or elements unless it has explicitly included. - Increase the difficulty of the question using variations but do not introduce new concepts. - Whenever a layout-based question is asked, provide a clear layout outline (diagram or text). - Evaluate the answered code based on correctness, structure, and sticking to the concept. - Provide constructive feedback and improvements. - Only proceed to the next question once i answered the question correctly and with sufficient understanding.
**1.2.4 Code Explanation:** Sometimes, you might come across a piece of code that is difficult to understand. Gen AI can break down the code into smaller, understandable steps.
Prompt
Act as an experienced teacher explaining a piece of code to a school student who has just learned the basics of HTML for creating static websites. First, explain what the given code does in simple terms. Then, break down the code into individual steps, explaining each step. Make sure the explanation is easy to understand and beginner-friendly **code**: """ """
